content.question: Which of the following best explains how molecules such as <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> can move across the membrane of a cell?

choices.label: The majority of the cell membrane contains protein channels that allow this type of molecule into the cell.
The majority of the cell membrane is nonpolar, which allows small, nonpolar molecules to freely cross.
The phospholipids of the membrane are tightly packed, so only small molecules and ions can fit between phospholipids.

<math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is hydrolyzed to provide energy to help <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> move against their concentration gradient and across the membrane.

content.answer: The majority of the cell membrane is nonpolar, which allows small, nonpolar molecules to freely cross.
